fullText: This multifaceted mix, often stirring and fascinating to listen to, is not an inherently logical choice for a narrative work of art — and yet, Justin Peck has devised, directed, and choreographed a 90-minute dance theater piece based on it, one that will indelibly be remembered as one of the most singular productions in recent Broadway history.
bwwExcerpt: Peck’s choreography is as marvelous as it is moving. Several dance motifs repeat, a nod to the theme of memory and haunting. Often these are tied to characters, like Carl and Henry’s balance-beam swaggering and swaying, or the side-by-side swing-inspired dance and handshake of Henry, Carl, and Shelby. Peck’s choreography is decidedly modern, but his ballet background informs the work, with long-line leg extensions at classic angles and a flurry of precisely-spotted spins and turns.

keyPhrases.quote: often stirring and fascinating to listen to
indelibly be remembered as one of the most singular productions in recent Broadway history
not an inherently logical choice for a narrative work of art

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: Despite acknowledging conceptual challenges, the critic praises the execution and declares it historically significant with superlative language. | GPT-4o-mini: The review expresses strong praise for the uniqueness and stirring quality of the production, indicating a clear recommendation despite some reservations about its narrative logic.
